description.title: Kepler Equation Solver (M → E → ν)
description.what: Solves Kepler's equation M = E - e·sin(E) for the eccentric anomaly E, then computes the true anomaly ν. Tests convergence across eccentricities.
description.why: Kepler's equation is fundamental to orbital mechanics. Different solvers (Newton-Raphson vs bisection) have different convergence properties.
description.units: E and ν errors in radians. Self-consistency residual in radians.
description.interpret: Lower residual = better convergence. Libnova's bisection method converges to ~1e-6 deg, while Newton-Raphson methods reach ~1e-15 rad.

alignment.time_input: JD (Julian Date), TT scale for precession/nutation, UT1 for sidereal time
alignment.time_scales: TT for BPN matrix; UT1≈TT-69.184s simplified
alignment.leap_seconds: not applicable (JD input, no UTC conversion in this experiment)

library_notes.astropy: The 'astropy' adapter calls ERFA/pyerfa C kernels directly from Python. Accuracy results are identical to ERFA. Performance results measure Python-loop + ERFA-kernel overhead, NOT the high-level astropy.coordinates stack.

models.astropy: Newton-Raphson iteration in Python (100 iters, tol 1e-15)
models.libnova: Sinnott bisection via ln_solve_kepler (internal convergence ~1e-6 deg)
models.anise: Not available in ANISE adapter for this experiment

alignment.accuracy_interpretation: accuracy vs ERFA reference (same equation, different solvers)
alignment.note: Kepler's equation M = E - e*sin(E) is solved for E given (M, e). Self-consistency M_reconstructed = E - e*sin(E) is the primary metric. libnova uses a bisection method with lower convergence tolerance.
